awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Sustainable Development-Research Experience for Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Teachers in Engineering and Computer Science Site: Sustainable Development-Research Experience for Teachers (SD-RET) at South Dakota School of Mines & Technology (SDSM&T) will expose middle and high school mathematics and science teachers in rural America to engineering and science research projects and a curriculum development strategies to improve the teaching and learning of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines. To align with the educational and training needs of the 21st century and to increase the interests of students, particularly underrepresented minorities, in learning STEM disciplines, the SD-RET provides the teachers an access to the various engineering and science technologies and the tools to integrate engineering/science projects into K-12 curriculum.

This SD-RET project will directly involve at least 30 rural teachers over the three project years. During the 6-week summer program each year, the rural teachers will conduct research in the engineering and science research laboratories at SDSM&T as research assistants (referred to as SD-RET RAs) with formal/informal mentoring from the faculty and graduate/undergraduate students. The engineering and science research projects will focus on implementing the technologies to address challenges in sustainable development such as air quality, water resources and treatment, sustainable energy, and sustainable materials. In addition, the SD-RET RAs will enroll in a 2-credit graduate course entitled "STEM Education in Secondary Classroom" for pedagogical and curriculum development training based on state and national standards. By integrating the lab research experience and curriculum development skills, the SD-RET RAs will translate their engineering and science research experience into their STEM curriculums. The SD-RET project will provide multiple follow-up activities to enable the implementation of the SD-RET experience. The SD-RET Assessment Advisory Board will evaluate the project and provide feedback for continuous improvement. Beyond the 30 SD-RET RAs, this project has the potential to extend impacts to colleagues of the SD-RET RAs at the same schools, pre-service teachers enrolling in the curriculum development course, and educators who access to the SD-RET website.

por.por_cntn:
The RET Site: Sustainable Development ? Research Experience for Teachers (RET) provided 31 K-12 educators from South Dakota (primarily), North Dakota and Colorado the opportunity to conduct research at South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SD Mines) and share their educational perspectives with SD Mines faculty and students.  Key features of this RET experience were the intense six-week research experience, Women in Science and Engineering Brown Bag series, and guidance in developing class appropriate lesson plans.  The RET K-12 Research Assistants (RA's) created posters or PowerPoint presentations summarizing their research experience and lesson plans.  The lesson plans incorporated skills and knowledge that were gained by the RET K-12 RA's during their research experience and were aligned with relevant state and national standards.  In addition, some RET K-12 RA's were co-authors on publications and presentations, pursued other RET opportunities and one RET RA submitted an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship application to support their goal of pursuing graduate school to enhance their STEM knowledge base for their K-12 teaching.  Long-term impacts included use of lesson plans impacting 100's of rural students, tours of SD Mines laboratories by K-12 educators and their students, and active relationships between RET K-12 RA's and SD Mines Faculty.  Faculty mentors and their students gained a much deeper understanding of the K-12 educators' perspectives and classroom educational requirements, which have been used to subsequently forge even more meaningful partnerships.
